comments.author: A&N
comments.content:
I love love love green mango. Tried slicing them into huge potato fry like wedges and sprinkling salt and cayenne on it? It is popular street food in India.

And now, you have my mouth watering :|

comments.author: John - Mormon Foodie
comments.content: Micheal, how is it you bring us such wonderful things all the time? I think the sesame oil is inspired.

comments.author: JMom
comments.content: You just made my mouth water :)

comments.author: Anja
comments.content: This salad is really extraordinary. I'll save this recipe for trying soon. It catched my attention on foodgawker. greetings and a nice weekend.

comments.author: hollynoel001h\
comments.content: very interesting take on a salad will have to try this soon

comments.author: Alessandra
comments.content: I knew of green papaya salad which uses a different type of papaya, not the one that then becomes orange and sweet. For this mango salad do you use a special type of mango or any mango is Ok, as long as still unripe?

comments.author: Camille
comments.content: that looks sooo good. i love mango.  are you going to do some thanksgiving receipes? i need some inspiration.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Thanks Camille! Re Thanksgiving, I have a stuffing recipe over at Serious Eats (and see my note in the comments as welll): http://bit.ly/7TtYnR. And this stuffed delicata makes a kill veg Thanksgiving entree: https://herbivoracious.com//2007/11/recipe-delicata.html.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN">
Yes, I have heard that there are other varieties which stay hard and can be used in these salads. But slightly underripe specimens of the typical varieties you find work really well too. A friend also told me that well stocked Vietnamese groceries will often have freshly shredded mango, made daily, that you can buy so all you have to do is mix up the salad.

comments.author: Bill
comments.content: Yuk! Without the Nam Pla this is nothing!

comments.author: Alex
comments.content: I really like these foods . I am Japanese and I eat with Chinese friends, Filipinos, Vietnamese, Cambodians and Koreans too. I make my own special kim chee. My neighbor is good for fish sauce. My Mom's specialty is rice dishes, shrimp, scallops, and sushi. My sister is great in Thai cooking and India dishes. I wish I could eat with you sometime! Tonight we are having some Green Tea Cookies and Red Bean Ice Cream. I wish you could have some too! Best of luck to you!!

comments.author: katie
comments.content: You've probably been there already, but in case you've missed it, the green mango salad at Wrap O Roll (on Jackson immediately east of where it crosses under I-5) is my current Seattle favorite.

comments.author: Thailand Breeze
comments.content:
I love mango!

The lime juice and fresh ginger also work wonders.

Great recipe.

comments.author: that guy
comments.content:
tasty recipe.

i didnt have any brown sugar, so i used three tablespoons of white sugar and added a tablespoon of molasses.

mmm, mmm good.

comments.author: Katie C.
comments.content:
Just discovered your blog a couple of weeks ago, and have enjoyed every post! I've got a question about this recipe: why do you soak the onions in cold water? Does it make them crisper? Take out a bit of the sharpness?

Thanks!

comments.author: Nadav
comments.content:
Great recipe! :) Everybody likes it when I bring this dish and this year many of my friends are going to make it for the holiday feasts :)

Keep on bring us great dishes!

Thanks,
Nadav

comments.author: Dawn
comments.content: This was SOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO good! I ate the whole bowl! It ended up being my lunch. Am thinking of going to get more mangos tmrw. I will make this again. And again. Talk about flavor bomb :)
